title: Shyvana is offensively and defensively weak and feels bad to play
body: This is a champion that has almost no utility, doesn't duel particularly well anymore and has a poor ganking kit. Having the ability to clear camps 2 seconds faster than other champs is really not cutting it as an advantage at this point in the game. She keeps going through goofy nerfs because of things like Feral Flare and Devourer but Riot never seems to prop her back up once the item gets removed.

This is pretty much the prime reason why Riot needs to stop taking bronze and silver into consideration when balancing.

What lower elo's consider "dumb" is usually what they just haven't bothered to learn how to play around. Shyvana's a champion who can always be kited out of a fight and who can be hard shut down with a single CC.

And to be frank, you're correct.  But playing champions that aren't built to kite or have unreliable CC make it more frustrating to fight her.  She's not alone in this however, I just dread a fed Shyvana in almost the same way I dread a fed Yi.

You don't even need to be playing a champion with reliable CC or strong kiting to kite out a Shyvana. You can do it as any champ with a slow or a dash, which is something like 95% of the roster assuming you don't engage on her. As long as you force her to use her R to engage she's super easy to kite out, I could see someone like Mord struggling but past that she's really easy to kite as literally anyone.

Yi is basically a more extreme version of Shyvana, one hard CC and he's done. He's not even a threat for the most part. In every case there should be someone on your team who can shut down Yi, if there's not you failed in champ select and deserve what you get.

Honestly I find slows to not be as effective when she as a speedup.  

I'm not trying to say she's toxic or anything.  I just don't like fighting Shyvana when she's fed and I personally find on hit playstyles to be unhealthy (just feels like stat checking to me).

Actually slows are disproportionately effective against speed up targets.

If you start with 325 ms, adding a 50% speed boost brings you to 487.5, then slowing for 50% drops her to 243.75. There's some softcap that applies to that lower number, but it's still lower than the base. This is before mentioning that Shyvana's MS boost decays meaning if you can keep distance for the first second she probably won't have the MS to catch you, also if she doesn't AA you it only lasts 3 seconds, which shouldn't be long enough for her to close the distance even a moderate slow from something like a Ashe AA would open.

>(just feels like stat checking to me).

There's far more options to play around Shyvana than there are to play around a meta jungler like Lee Sin or Elise TBH. As long as those champs don't fuck up there's nothing you could do to beat them. Shyvana just has so few options available to her at any given time that it's realistic to play around all of them. The same is true of most "stat check" champions.

I'm reading this as, "Stat checking is healthy".  Which I wouldn't agree with.  Obviously you're always going to have some level of it, but an entire kit shouldn't be based around who has the bigger numbers and your opponents inability to outplay you.

Stat checking is more healthy than the absurd kits with multiple options for every situation.

The problem with the game at present is that champions like Lee Sin, Elise, Fiora and Thresh are just given so many options that in the hands of a player who understands them they can respond to everything. 

There is no correct play you can make into a Lee Sin, there's better and worse plays but ultimately he always has a play that beats your play. You cannot beat a Lee Sin using correct strategy if he plays well enough. This is far more destructive to the game than stat check champs.

> [{quoted}](name=LankPants,realm=OCE,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=HZmjRJ7I,comment-id=000100000001000000000000000000000000,timestamp=2017-07-06T15:45:38.639+0000)
>
> Stat checking is more healthy than the absurd kits with multiple options for every situation.
> 

...no it really isn't.  Yes it is frustrating to deal with champions with those kits, but they do have room to actually fuck up their abilities and get outplayed.  Obviously there should be a limit to what a champion's kit can offer, but in no way is a kit based entirely around having more stats that your opponent more healthy than a kit that can outplay and be outplayed.

> The problem with the game at present is that champions like Lee Sin, Elise, Fiora and Thresh are just given so many options that in the hands of a player who understands them they can respond to everything. 
> 

And when faced against champions with similar strengths like that, it boils down to individual skill.

> There is no correct play you can make into a Lee Sin, there's better and worse plays but ultimately he always has a play that beats your play. You cannot beat a Lee Sin using correct strategy if he plays well enough. This is far more destructive to the game than stat check champs.

Except that isn't true at all.  Even if a Lee knows how to mechanically play the champion, he isn't a robot.  He can make mistakes, mistakes that can be exploited.  It's not easy to see this in champions like Lee sure, but in champions like Yasuo who have to play aggressive, it becomes painfully obvious.

Stat checking is not healthier than this.  Stat checking revolves around having higher stats and hoping that your opponent lacks the tools to outplay you.  If you fall behind on a stat checking champion, you're basically useless and unable to contribute much at all.  I don't see how you find that healthy.

>Stat checking is not healthier than this. Stat checking revolves around having higher stats and hoping that your opponent lacks the tools to outplay you. If you fall behind on a stat checking champion, you're basically useless and unable to contribute much at all. I don't see how you find that healthy.

Replace tools with basic level of knowledge.

If statchecking worked the way you think it does you'd see high elo players, maybe even in pro games saying "their team is incredibly weak to Rammus, he'd be a great pick here". The fact that that never happens shows that isn't actually how it works.

You can counter every stat check champion in the game bar Tryndamere by just playing correctly around them, Tryndamere just requires you to win a majority of 70/30s in the early game which is a terrible design. Still every other champion like this you can beat by just understanding them, which is why they're practically nonexistent by high gold.

Problem with the "mechanical" champs is that they can statcheck aswel. So you have to outplay both their play aswel as there statcheck. Examples; leesin misses q but still runs you down with his high base ms, fiora when she ults (dont think this needs more expanation), old tankekko,...
Remember yasuo a few patches back? Sure he could make beautifull plays and 1v3 but he could just aswel compelety miss his tornado and his windwall and he would still kill 1 with just aa and e.

>Stat checking is not healthier than this. Stat checking revolves around having higher stats and hoping that your opponent lacks the tools to outplay you. If you fall behind on a stat checking champion, you're basically useless and unable to contribute much at all. I don't see how you find that healthy.

Stat checking champs have way less tools to fall backto if shit goes wrong so its more when  and where to fight than the actual fight itself and i dont know if that is such a bad thing. It rewards macro play a lot more. Arent overextending without wards or lettng a nassus ffreefarm just as bad a mistakes as missing a mechanial ability? I played mundo vs morderkaiser the other day. Pre 9 i get desroyed in that matchup after 11 i destroy him (ofcourse snowballing one way or the other not withstanding) and i had a lot of fun trying to not fall to far behind vs him doing everything he can to put me in the durt. Now even with the fact that he would clearly win the statcheck pre lvl 9 i can still play around his cooldown and jungle to keep in there. And is it really that diferent from lets say vayne vs lucian? 

in conclusion; yeah pure statcheck is bad(garen, yi)  but that doenst make statcheck a bad design by default. A statcheck champion with a few abilites is often better than an overloaded kit because the champ with the overloaded kit will often end up statchecking aswel

Obviously extremes are poor designs.  I'm trying to say that pure stat checking designs (which is how I personally view Shyvana) are unhealthy for the game, more so than even pure mechanical designs (though pure mechanical designs are unhealthy as well).  

Stat checking in it of itself in unavoidable.  That's basically what happens when auto attacks meet resistance.  But we shouldn't encourage or even praise high stat check designs as they're just honestly bad.

I'm pretty excited to have this discussion. Shyv is one of my favorite champions but I can also see the many areas she's lacking.

I feel her passive is essentially a different form of Warwick's blood hunt ability. It's a constant "hey, there's something on the map you should be doing right now". Her passive is like a voice in your head reminding you that your JOB is dragon control at all costs. For that reason I think her passive helps new jungle players to focus on controlling the dragon. But, that leaves much to be desired. The reward she gets from perfectly securing dragons isnt worth it and the penalty for having a bad game is crushing. I'd like to see her passive reworked into something that actually helps her throughout the game even if she's not securing every single dragon on spawn. 

Another problem I have with her is how predictable she is. Once she presses W you know she's just going to run at you and hope she kills you before she has no way of catching you anymore. Anyone with mobility can kite her into oblivion. 

I love the concept she brings to the table as a half dragon badass, but her usefulness comes solely from getting fed and stat checking until the game is over. She offers very little in terms of outplay potential.
